title: Nick recounts advice from his father about reserving judgement, leading to both positive and negative social experiences. He reflects on his tolerance having limits, particularly towards the riotous excursions into the human heart. Nick expresses scorn for Gatsby, yet acknowledges something gorgeous about him, a heightened sensitivity and extraordinary gift for hope, but notes that something preyed on Gatsby and closed out Nick's interest in men's sorrows.
text:
I

In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice
that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.

“Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone,” he told me, “just
remember that all the people in this world haven’t had the advantages
that you’ve had.”

He didn’t say any more, but we’ve always been unusually communicative
in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more
than that. In consequence, I’m inclined to reserve all judgements, a
habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me
the victim of not a few veteran bores. The abnormal mind is quick to
detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal
person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of
